So, I was sitting around at work today and I decided that the progress on my autobiography was going too slow. See, I was writing it out in pieces in a notebook, but I wasn't spending that much time sitting down writing in this notebook. So, I decided that I would put bits and pieces of it in the notebook as they come to me and put parts up here as well.  So, I decided that today I am going to post my introduction section to my memoirs.  The book is called Tube Socks and Bandannas: The Odyssey of a Completely (ab)Normal American Boy.  The introduction goes as follows:

I'm sure you might be wondering why a 21 year-old guy who really hasn't done anything special or vitally important with his life is writing his autobiography.  How can he have some kind of life story that needs to be told?  To be honest, I wondered the same thing myself when I decided to write my memoirs.  When I told people older than me about my plans to write my autobiography, I was scoffed at because I "haven't even really experienced life yet" or "haven't done anything" with my life that warrants the writing of my memoirs.  As I thought about that, I found that I think my life story really does need to be told.  Sure, I haven't done anything really noteworthy in my life, but that doesn't mean I haven't experienced life.  It's quite the contrary really.

 

I made the decision to write my memoirs after taking the time to think about what, if anything sets me and my life apart from everyone else around my age, thus making my story one worth telling.  When I really contemplated it, the thought occurred to me that I've never been quite like any other person I know.  I've always been a bit eccentric and my thought processes never really matched up with other kids my age.  While other kids in my second grade class were worrying about recess, I was ruminating over Ross Perot's hour-long presidential campaign advertisements and whether or not George H.W. Bush would win re-election in 1992.

 

In high school other kids were partying, trying to get nice cars, and listening to rap; I was kicking it in tube socks and bandannas, driving a 13 year-old station wagon, and listening to cock rock like KISS, Poison, and Guns N' Roses.  When other kids were working at the gas station or at a restaurant, I was at Thacher Park working with a future Howard Stern Wack Packer and having some of the most bizarre experiences of my life.  When the kids I knew at school were getting pumped up for prom, I was becoming a polemicist due to President Bush's War in Iraq.

 

My college years have thus far been an affirmation of my time in high school.  I've made a good amount of friends and acquaintances, but I still don't think i truly "fit in" with the majority of people my age.  I never really cared to have a clique that I could fit in with and I haven't lived through my Sundays, Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays for the sole purpose of getting fucked up on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays.  While the others were drinking, I was being Santa Claus and the Easter Bunny at the mall.  Doing things to fit in or due to a group mentality never held any interest to me.  I guess in my regards my mentality has been that of a solipsist.

          When it comes down to it, I think that my life is absolutely one that has been worth telling.  I have pretty much marched to the beat of my own drummer my whole life and I think that in this time where current society preaches conformity and mindlessness, that my life story could be considered a breath of fresh air and proof that not EVERYONE is a drone.  As I see it, the first 21 years of my life have been an example of the American Dream in action.  I mean, what is more American and democratic than being an individual and acting on free will?

           Alright, maybe the American Dream spiel was a bit of an exaggeration and my life story isn't THAT vital or necessary.  But, have you ever seen some of the shitty autobiographies that have been released?  Who the fuck cares about some of these people who publish their memoirs?  My life has been just as interesting and much more true.  I mean if Michael "Lord of the Dance" Flatley can have an autobiography, why the fuck can't I?  Tube socks and bandannas are much more interesting than spandex and a glittery headband anyways.

Not going to lie, tonite was the biggest waste of time in my entire life.  Sienafest is/was this weekend and I usually try to avoid it like the plague.  I mean, I drink occasionally, but I have no real desire to spend a whole day getting trashed, watching the campus get fucked up, and hurdling over puddles of vomit in the hallway.  For one nite only however, I decided to stick around for at least partof Sienafest.  The main reason I did this was because my roommate had to be on RA duty Friday nite/Saturday morning and we figured we would chill since he couldn't really drink or hang out with his other friends.  As it turns out, I think I ended up seeing him for like five minutes since he did in fact hang with his other friends before he had to work.  But whatever, its not that big of a deal in the grand scheme of things and contrary to what he thinks I think, I'm not mad at him.  He's a good guy and I'm glad he had a good time with his posse.

I guess the real reason I am kind of disgruntled has to do with girl troubles.  There is this girl that I am kind of interested in and I thought maybe she was interested in me, but I don't think I was right at all.  There is a serious lack of communication between the two of us that is certainly not conducive to the development of a relationship of any sorts, even if its just that of friendship.  But that is what happens when the only avenue of conversation is instant fucking messenger because you rarely see said person and don't know her phone number.  Despite that hindrance, it seemed like a few weeks ago everything was floating along ok.  I even overcame my own insecurities and doubts to ask her if she wanted to hang out.  She said yes (surprisingly to me), but plans fell through when she ended up having to work until 1:30 in the morning.  She seemed pretty apologetic and it kind of sucked that plans fell through, but shit happens (or snakes on a plane or whatever that new stupid fucking phrase is) and I pretty much got over that.

From that point on, I would say that things entered what I refer to as a non-relationship.  I would leave a message here and there, to no response.  I was kind of perturbed about that, but the J-Cat told me that she was having issues with her ex-boyfriend or something.  While I can understand how much that kind of shit sucks, I tried my best to at least be a nice guy/friend type to see if she wanted to just talk or something, but nothing arose from that.

By this stage (which was like the week before Easter), I was feeling pretty down in the dumps because it felt like I wasn't getting outright rejected or getting any positive reaction either.  Then, over the Easter Break it hit me that there is really no reason to be upset about anything.  I made a decision that I would just essentially be who I always am and not really let stupid bullshit like relationships (or lack of) get me down.  I decided that I would just let the chips fall where they may.  As it turned out, it seemed like this new perspective was working, as we talked earlier in the week and I felt things went well.  She said she didn't really plan on drinking or even hanging out around campus during Sienafest.  I extended the invitation for her to hang out here and watch a movie or something and I thought that she seemed pretty receptive, although noncommital, to the idea.

Now, I pretty much figured the whole time that she wasn't going to stop by.  I'm nothing if not a realist.  She said that she was either going to hang out with her friend who had to work all nite or go hang out at a friend's house off-campus.  There really wasn't anything that would make me really believe that she was going to stop by tonite and I was right.  It was one of those rare instances where I was not too happy to be correct.  Even though I knew she wasn't going to stop by, I kind of hoped she would.  See, I just thought it would be a pretty pleasant surprise if she was to stop over, even if it was just to simply say hello.  I also figured that hey, even if she didn't stop by, at least I would be hanging out with the roommate and that would be fun.  Too bad that didn't really work out either.  Instead, I basically sat around all nite and did pretty much nothing.  The most time consuming part of my evening was watching part of WWE's Bret "The Hitman" Hart DVD.

If there is a lesson to be learned, its that I really need to chill the fuck out and not expect so much from people and really stop trying to hang out with this girl.  I mean, it seems like I let myself get all wound up over and for nothing and I really don't want to do that.  As I finish typing this, its like 3 am and I think I'm going to bed.  Maybe I'll update again soon.....

I still haven't written anything for my memoirs lately, as I have been busy with school and being the Easter Bunny. My state of mind has been pretty hectic lately, but I don't really feel like writing about it right now. However, if some things don't change or my mind is still racing, I'll let all three of you who still read this know what the deal is. Instead, what I'm going to write about is something else that has been on my mind, but has nothing to do with me personally. It's a music review/commentary. I figured that since I want to write so fucking much, I might as well mix it up a bit and try something other than my political rants. The topic is Guns N' Roses, who have been in the news a lot lately with rumors abounding over a tour and maybe the release of Chinese Democracy (Which I'm about to explain). So this will basically just read like an article or cd review (hopefully).

Since the release of 1993's punk cover album The Spaghetti Incident?, Guns N' Roses has essentially been silent on the music scene.  Axl Rose has become the JD Salinger and Howard Hughes of the music scene, spending the last decade in silence and seclusion.  In 1995, Axl was promising a new sound and direction for the band, with the music becoming more industrial ala Nine Inch Nails.  While working on the new album, called Chinese Democracy, every original member of Guns, minus keyboard player Dizzy Reed, has either been fired or quit the band.  Bassist Duff McKagan, drummer Matt Sorum, and beloved lead guitarist Slash eventually formed the band Velvet Revolver with former Stone Temple Pilots frontman Scott Weiland and released their debut album in 2004.  The album was fairly successful, but it was criticized as uninspired and lacking.

In 1999, Axl and his new Guns N' Roses came out of hiding when their song "Oh My God" was released on the soundtrack to the film End of Days.  This song received mostly negative comments from the critics, who disliked the techno/industrial undertones in the song and considered it by and large a waste of time and studio time.  Around this time, there was a release date confirmed for Chinese Democracy, but it was shelved at the last minute.  After this, Axl wasn't heard from again until 2001's Rock in Rio, where Axl returned to the stage with his brand new Gunners.  In this band were former Replacements bassist Tommy Stinson, former Nine Inch Nails touring guitarist Robin Finck, former Primus drummer Brain, and the mysterious Buckethead, a seven-feet tall man who wears a mask like Jason and a KFC bucket on his head.  The "return" of Guns N' Roses created quite a stir and received a great deal of publicity and rumors of Chinese Democracy's release swirled again.  Unfortunately for Guns fans, this wasn't meant to be and Axl went back into seclusion.

In 2002, Axl and the new Guns made a surprise appearance at the MTV Video Music Awards.  This was really the first time that the mainstream audience had been exposed to the new Guns N' Roses and they were in for quite a shock when they saw Buckethead, the gothic Finck, and Axl Rose sporting a baggy football jersey and braided hair instead of his trademark kilt and red mane.  Shortly after this a world tour was launched, but to no avail.  Axl missed the first show on the tour and ticket sales were not impressive, due to a lack of an album to support and any real buzz about the band.  This started to change at a show in Madison Square Garden that received a great deal of critical acclaim, but the tour went up in flames when Axl failed to show up at the next show in Philadelphia.  After this, a second cancelled show, Clear Channel pulled the plug on the tour with half the dates remaining.  Any hopes of the new album were dashed and Axl wasn't heard from again until he issued a press release concerning the departure of Buckethead in 2004.  This release stated that news on Chinese Democracy would be forthcoming.

Nothing again was heard about the album until recently, when four new songs were leaked on the internet.  As these leaks made the rounds, Slash gave an interview in which he stated that the new Guns album was going to come out soon.  Axl and his former bandmates made the news through lawsuits directed at each other.  Axl and the band have confirmed 20 shws in Europe this summer, but no one knows if he'll show up or who is even in the band.  Buckethead's departure leaves a gap in the lead guitar position and no one is really sure if anyone else has come or gone, since Axl made anyone who worked on Chinese Democracy with him sign a gag order.  Current rumors say that Slash is rejoining the band, but no one has come close to confirming that.  Rumors and news releases have stated that the album was coming out March 28, but that obviously hasn't happened.  Another rumor from Clear Channel Entertainment has it coming out in April and others are stating that Axl is planning to release it in September.  Regardless, the buzz around Axl and Guns N' Roses has never been stronger.

Since no one really knows what will be on the album, what follows is a review of new songs that have been played live on the 2002 tour or leaked over the last few months.  Some of the songs have been confirmed by Axl in Rolling Stone in 2000 and in January of this year as being on the album.  A couple of the songs have been confirmed as not appearing on the album, but no one is really sure until the album is released (if it ever actually is released).  The reviews that follow start with 1999's "Oh My God" since it may or may not also appear on the album, and ends with the latest leak, "Catcher in the Rye."

Oh My God - As stated before, this came from End of Days.  None other than guitarist to the stars Dave Navarro plays the lead guitar on this.  Although this track received a lot of flak from music critics, I enjoy it.  It has the vintage Axl Rose wail and a pretty heavy riff that sounds distinctly Guns N' Roses, but with industrial overtones.  There is a bit of a techno dance groove underneath the riff that is pretty interesting.  Lyrically, it isn't amazing but overall I think it is a decent modern rock track.  I'm pretty sure that if it was released now, it would be received much better.  When it came out in 1999, the argument could be made that Axl was trying to stay current with other industrial acts, but now this sound would be pretty unique when compared to other popular rock tracks.  While it is a pretty good rock song, there really isn't anything overly memorable about it that would make it a "great" song.  I personally would give this track an 8 out of 10.

Silk Worms - This song was performed at Rock in Rio in 2001.  The version I am revieiwing is the Rio one.  It wasn't written by Axl, but by keyboardists Dizzy Reed and Chris Pittman.  Dizzy has since said in interviews that this track will not make it onto Chinese Democracy and rightly so.  It is easily the weakest of all the new tracks.  It is drum and keyboard based, with a pretty cool guitar hook in the chorus.  Lyrically it is lacking and it is pretty stupid.  I mean, most Guns N' Roses songs are about being wronged by a woman, but this one is pretty stupid.  I don't hate this song, but it is definitely not album worthy.  It is probably a 5 out of 10 at most.

Rhiad and the Bedouins - This song was performed in 2001 at Rio and early on in some of the 2002 shows.  The version I have is from a Las Vegas show in 2001 or 2002.  Rumor has it that this won't be on the album and that's a bit of shame.  It has a great funky, heavy guitar line to it that is vintage Buckethead.  Lyrically it isn't amazing, but the vocals on it are compelling and it is always nice to hear Axl scream his ass off.  The solo is cool and you can hear the industrial influence on it in the keyboards.  It has an old Guns feel to it, but the new direction is also evident.  I would give this song about an 8 out of 10.

Madagascar - This song was played at Rio, the VMA performance, and at each show on the 2002 tour.  My version is from a 2002 show.  This song has grown on me over time.  It is keyboard driven and more of a midtempo epic.  It really doesn't sound much like older Guns N' Roses material musically, as it has more of a techno feel to it than a song like "November Rain" or one of the older ballads.  There is a cool guitar solo on it and Axl has some pretty good vocals on it, but the middle of the song has this weird breakdown with a bunch of random voice clips from movies.  All in all, this song manages to successfully pull off that epic feel and I would give it an 8.5 of 10 since it is such a compelling listen.

The Blues - This song has been performed live since Rio and the version I have is from a 2002 show.  This song is very much in the vein of the classic ballads like "Estranged" and "November Rain."  It very much retains that classic GNR sound, with a melodic piano melody and Axl lamenting on unrequited love.  Of the new songs, this is probably the best in terms of lyrics.  This is probably the most traditional Guns N' Roses sounding song, as the industrial sounds are very muted and the keyboards are only providing ambient background noise.  If the album ever comes out, this song will definitely be a single.  I'm a big fan of it, so I would give it a 9 out of 10.

Chinese Democracy - This is another one that has been performed live consistently since Rock in Rio.  I have 2 versions of this song, one from Rio and one from 2002 and they both sound slightly different from one another.  I would assume the 2002 one is more like the version that would appear on the album, as it sounds more refined and familiar to the band than it did at the Rio show.  This one really shows the direction Axl is going in musically.  The riff is pretty heavy and the keyboard plays along with it, giving it kind of a Nine Inch Nails vibe.  Overall, this song rocks pretty hard, but it isn't particularly memorable and it certainly shouldn't be a single, as it is kind of simple lyrically and melodically.  However, it sounds like it will be a pretty good album track and I would give it an 8 out of 10.

Catcher In The Rye - This was the fourth demo track from the album leaked.  It has a vibe and melody that is similar to a band such as Queen.  That could be because Brian May of Queen does the lead guitar work on it.  Allegedly, this song is about John Lennon's assassination as through the eyes of Mark David Chapman, his assassin.  This track is heavy on the piano and melody and Axl keeps his screeching off the track and it sounds like he's really trying to have a harmony.  Overall, this track doesn't really sound much like any of the other new songs or the old material, not that that's a bad thing.  I think this is a pretty good song and I could definitely see it getting radio play as a single.  I would give it an 8.5 out of 10.

I.R.S. - This was the first studio demo to be leaked.  It is kind of a shock at first, as it starts off mellow and features a programmed drum loop.  After about a minute in, Buckethead comes in with a pretty sick guitar riff that livens up the song and leads into Axl screeching like its still 1992.  Unfortunately, it stays kind of midtempo for most of the song.  When the song rocks and Buckethead gets to let loose, "I.R.S." is at its best.  Lyrically, it isn't exactly brilliance.  Axl is railing against a woman who broke his heart and is swearing to send the government after her in revenge.  However, it is nice to hear that ridiculous Axl Rose screech.  I would give this song a 7.5 out of 10.  I rated it that low because, even though I enjoyed it, it really isn't that great a song other than Axl's vocals and the brief passage where Buckethead gets to bring the rock.

There Was A Time -  This is the second leaked song.  It opens with another programmed drum beat and a keyboard melody, but the guitar kicks in around the chorus.  It stays mid-tempo throughout and seems like a logical follow-up to the older material.  There is a lot of keyboard/electronics mixed in with the regular band, so there is a lot to digest in the song.  Axl, of course, is railing about another woman who's done him wrong.  I do think that this song would be a bit better if there was less going on in it, but as is, this demo is a pretty good song.  It could definitely be released as a single once it is cleaned up.  I would say it is an 8.5 out of 10.

Better - "Better" was the third leaked track, and is by far the best of the bunch.  This one most successfully combines rock with the electronic/industrial themes that Axl was going for.  It opens just above mid-tempo, with Axl singing about a failed relationship.  The opening riff has a good melody and it really sounds like Axl means what he's singing.  When the song hits the chorus, the industrial themes are evident and it sounds similar to "Oh My God."  It then goes back to the original melody in the verse, which is catchy and pleasing.  Then, the song hits the chorus again and goes into an obvious Buckethead passage.  The riff gets really heavy and a shredding solo hits, leading into a heavy breakdown with Axl screaming like he hasn't in years.  I personally think that one of the reasons this song is so good is the combination of a good melody by Axl and noticeable playing by Buckethead, as parts of the song sound just like his playing.  If I was Axl Rose, this would be the first single because it would definitely be a hit.  I would give this song a 10 out of 10.  It has it all: melody, heaviness, interesting lyrics and some shredding from Buckethead.

Only time will tell if Chinese Democracy will ever see the light of day.  I always had my doubts, especially after the 2002 tour debacle, but it seems like there really is a good chance that it might come out this year.  It's hard to say that any album is worth a 13 year wait, but I think that if it actually comes out it will easily be the best rock album this year.  I liked the Velvet Revolver album, but the demos alone are of a better quality and much more interesting to listen to than the entire VR album.

Well, my grandfather died today.  It wasn't a surprise; we knew this was going to happen soon.  I found out earlier today that he was in pretty bad shape, bad enough shape that today was the first time I have ever seen my father cry.  Then, my brother, mother and I went out to get dinner and we got the call that he died.  I was waiting for this day for a long time, so I was taking it pretty well.  Joe almost passed out, the poor kid.  Even on the ride home I was doing fine, until I called my grandparents in Vegas to tell them the news.  Telling people you love that a person you all loved just died is the toughest thing I have ever done and I really hope I don't have to do it again.  At the tail end of that call, I lost it for a minute.  Then, later on in the ride, I cried some more just reminiscing about the times years ago when he lived next door to us and we used to go over there daily.  There are a lot of really great memories of the times spent at that house.  When I got home, I did the only thing that I thought was right.  I went to my room and I put on one of his old Ella Fitzgerald cds that I borrowed from his house a long time ago.  I just sat down, listened to the music, and wept harder than I have in a long long time.  And really, honestly, I feel a lot better about it.  It was more of a cry for the memories and the loss, even though I hadn't spent a siginificant amount of time near him in ages.  And really, its ok now.

Needless to say, the Vegas trip has been postponed a few days until after the funeral service.  I guess I need to get a suit tomorrow for the wake and the funeral.  My dad asked if I would be a pallbearer.  I said yes.  I've never done that before, so let's hope I don't fuck it up.  It's weird because this is the first time in my life that someone I've been close to has died.  I've never been to a wake or funeral before, so this is going to be a first.  I guess I'll write about it in here at some point this week.

Alright, I'm done.  I'm tired and I have to be to work at 7 am.  I'll update again soon.

I felt like updating my journal today, but I don't really have anything of value to write about.  Also, I'm kind of bored as I type this, so what you get is this entry.  The last time I did a mixtape entry, I just listed the songs and my thoughts on them.  This time, I am going to do that, but maybe hopefully shorten my thoughts and add a rating to each song.  Ratings will be done on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being an atrocity and 10 being superfucking awesome.  There might be some songs that I rate lower than others, but still like more and that's because my ratings also factor in the expectation I have in terms of quality from each musician.  At the end, I'll compile a score based on the ratings and give the cd an overall percent rating.  This pattern will hold true for all mix cds and any cd reviews I decide to do.  I have way too much time on my hands.

The theme of this mix is songs that have come out within the past 3 years:

1. Megalomaniac by Incubus - I put this on here because I hadn't heard it in ages and it happens to be one of my favorite Incubus songs.  How can you not love a song that references Elvis AND Jesus at the same time?  But yeah, this song has a lot going for it:  great hook, great vocals, great lyrics.  I almost bought this cd for the sake of this song, but when I previewed the album it seemed that the other songs didn't match with the quality.  This one is 8.5/10

2. The Hand That Feeds by Nine Inch Nails - This is the newest NIN song, off their album that just came out this week.  It's really catchy and there aren't many people who can combine catchy with intensity both musically and lyrically like Trent Reznor.  Just like classic NIN songs, it has catchy lyrics and music, but still has that venom to its lyrics.  While it ain't Head Like a Hole, it certainly lives up to expectations.  Let's say 8.5/10

3. Your Time Has Come by Audioslave - The newest Audioslave single, off their soon to be released album.  This song sounds like a cross between MC5 and Hendrix, with the usual Morello guitar sound.  It's a pretty good rocker and I'm sure radio will play the shit out of it.  It sounds a tad different than the rockers off their last album, with less of the distortion and effects that Morello was known for in Rage.  Let's give it 7.5/10.

4. Metalingus by Alterbridge - Alterbridge is the band that is basically Creed, but with a different singer.  I came across this song because it is currently being used as the theme song for WWE wrestler Edge.  That being said, this song is a lot better than anything Creed did.  The band isn't plodding and boring like they were on Creed songs and the singer is much more dynamic than Scott Stapp.  Actually, the vocalist sounds a lot like Jeff Buckley and his vocals on this song remind me a lot of the Buckley song Eternal Life.  The singer has an amazing range and the band really steps up on it.  I still won't buy the album, but I won't hate on them like I did with Creed.  Let's go 8.5/10

5. Little Sister by Queens of the Stone Age - This is the first single off their recent release Lullabies to Paralyze.  At first I didn't like this song, but it has since grown on me.  It isn't anywhere near the quality of the songs on Rated R or Songs for the Deaf, but it is catchy and fun, two qualities lacking in a lot of newer rock bands and their singles.  It has a garage rock vibe going with the classic QOTSA sound, but the rhythm section is lacking the heaviness of the last two albums.  Still, its a solid rock song and I'll go with 7/10

6. Better Now by Collective Soul - In a more just world, this would be a major hit on the pop-rock stations.  It's insanely catchy and has the big crunchy guitar riffs that Collective Soul is known for.  Lyrically and musically its a bit simplistic, but it's a great song to hear them play live and it's a fun one to blast and sing along to.  It really isn't much more than slick produced, great sounding power pop, but sometimes thats OK.  Let's give this one 8/10.

7. Breakin' by the Music - I stumbled onto this song accidentally this week when flipping through the music choice channels on the cable box.  I loved their first single, Take the Long Road and Walk It, and this one is just as good.  It combines a trippy, psychedelic riff like early Jane's Addiction and combines it with Zeppelin.  The singer does a better Perry Farrell on this song than Perry Farrell has done lately.  The lyrics aren't brilliant, but they are fun and let the vocalist show off his range.  This is a fun, groove oriented song that one can dance to, if one is so inclined to get up and get down to a song.  I'm going to give it 8.5/10

8. Almost by Bowling for Soup - I don't mind Bowling for Soup, but I'm not in love with them either.  1985 was good at first before it got killed by radio and VH1.  This song isn't stand out, but since I saw the video I've had it stuck in my head.  It sounds really familiar and the reason why came to me recently; Butch Walker co-wrote and produced their album and this song has the same exact melody as his "#1 Summer Jam."  I mean, the chorus and the bridge are the same exact thing, except on his own song, Butch played it acoustic and had different lyrics.  This is one of the lower rated songs on the mix with a 6.5/10.  I enjoy it and all, but I anticipate tiring of and loathing it within a month, since it isn't a particularly brilliant piece of power pop.

9. Hiro's Song by Ben Folds - Ben Folds has pretty much mastered power pop.  Most of his uptempo songs are pretty clever and witty and this one is no exception.  It's about an older man who is dating a younger woman and it is your typical solid Ben Folds song.  The quality of musicianship on this song is good and I don't really have that much to say about it.  It's a 7/10

10. Hell Yeah by American Hi-Fi - This is the end of my power pop trilogy here.  Another song written and produced by Butch Walker, a catchy gem that makes up for the fact that I can't stand American Hi-Fi.  Seriously, I think they suck.  But this is well produced and written power pop that has Butch Walker's hands all over it.  Seriously, since when did American Hi-Fi know how to harmonize or craft a tight pop piece?  I'm gonna go with 7/10

11. Be Yourself by Audioslave - This is the Audioslave song that is being overplayed on radio and tv.  I can't hold that against it though; I'm a sucker for Chris Cornell and the Rage guys.  It is similar to Like A Stone with its intro, but it holds its own as a power ballad.  Cornell's voice is front and center on this one and he doesn't disappoint.  It isn't amazing, but I still like it more than Your Time Has Come.  This puppy gets 8.5/10

12. Tangled Up in Plaid by Queens of the Stone Age - This one is also off Lullabies to Paralyze and is one of my favorite tracks on that album.  This one won't get played on the radio, but that's ok.  It is classic QOTSA, with an unsettling rhythm, thick riffs, and weird vocals.  Vastly superior to Little Sister, it gets a 7.5/10

13. Sick Love Song by Motley Crue - Far superior to that Simple Plan written trash that the Crue released as the first single off their greatest hits.  This song is by far the best song Motley has done since Dr. Feelgood.  It has the trashy, brash, cock rock sound that makes the Crue one of my favorite guilty pleasure bands of alltime.  If you like/love Motley Crue, this song fucking rules and if you can't stand them, you'll probably hate it.  In my not so humble opinion this song fucking rules and I'm going to give it a 10/10.  It is everything one wants from Motley Crue and you can't ask for more than that.

14. 15. 17. Alive and Amplified by the Mooney Suzuki - Ah, the garage band that is actually really good.  Too bad they don't get played or hyped on the radio by anyone other than Little Steven.  Simply put, the Mooney Suzuki are the best of the whole garage band craze of the last few years.  They have put out some great garage rock albums over the last few years and this song (and the band in general) rocks without being pretentious, which is more than you can say about the Strokes.  Not as blatantly derivative as Jet and much more naturally raw than the Strokes and the Hives, the Mooney Suzuki rule.  This song, while slickly produced, has that retro rock feel of the 60s and 70s, but without that feel that you've heard it before.  I'm gonna give it an 8/10

18. Dirty Little Thing by Velvet Revolver - This is their current single and even though I own the album, it took a while for me to like this one.  I think thats because its the 12th song on the cd and it sounds EXACTLY like track 1, Sucker Train Blues.  However, on its own I enjoy it greatly.  It has that familiar sound of GNR and STP, but it still manages to not sound old and tired.  It has a lot of energy and is a perfectly acceptable piece of arena rock for this decade.  7.5/10

19. BYOB by System of a Down - This is the current single for the new System album.  I love it.  It has several changes in tempo and tone.  Some times its metal, some times its funk, and at others its punk.  And, it takes some serious shots at President Bush, which is always a plus.  It has the classic System sound, but if you're a fan you can tell that they have grown musically over the past few years.  And, like in Cigaro, the creepy guitarist has some time to sing.  This is easily my favorite new rock single this year and gets a 10/10 without any doubt.

And actually, tonite is your lucky nite.  I'm going to give a list of the bands/artists that I think are the ten best of all time.  These aren't my ten most favorite, these are the ten best and most important of all time as seen through my near-sighted eyes.  What I want from anyone who reads this is to email, IM, or leave me a a comment that provides YOUR top ten list of the best artists of all time.  I'm not ranking mine, but feel free to rank yours.  IF there's enough feedback from you, I'll compile them into a list and post them.  I'll set a weeklong deadline so you, my dedicated fanbase, can mull on it and provide your best list possible, since odds are I'm the only loser besides the people on VH1 who sits around and thinks about a topic like this.  I'm only going to give brief commentary after each artist on my list; you can as well, but it isn't required.  Well, enough of that..on with my list.

The Beatles: An obvious pick, but one that is deserved.  I wrote an entry on them a while ago, so this is going to be a short comment.  Regardless of what anyone thinks about their music, they paved the way for basically every other pop/rock band after them.  They defined what a band and an album could do and be like, not to mention they were the first band to be a global phenomenon.

The Doors: One of my favorite bands of all time and really revolutionary for their time.  Jim Morrison's not only my favorite frontman, but I am pretty sure he is the greatest lead singer of all time.  The band was great and as a whole, all four of the Doors changed what music could be.  They were doing 15 minute songs in 1965 about taboo topics like sex, drugs, and things that are now commonplace in music.  Also, singers from every generation have tried to do that Jim Morrison vocal style -  the Cult and Creed being most notorious.  To wrap this one up, the Doors were the darkest and most volatile band of their generation and created a legacy and songs that stand up to pretty much anything else ever recorded.

Led Zeppelin: The most imitated hard rock band of all time.  Each musician in that band is arguably the best of all time at the instrument they play.  I could name all their great songs, but that's an entry in and of itself.  Its nearly impossible to listen to any rock band and not hear a trace of something Zeppelin has done.

The Clash: More than just an amazing punk band, an amazing band in general.  The London Calling album mixes punk, pop, rockabilly, jazz, blues, and reggae throught its 20 songs.  They took punk and went beyond it, crafting real songs and pushing a real agenda, not just presenting anger and frustration.  Their songs had some sort of meaning to them and as I have said before, the Clash is the band U2 wishes they could be.

The Who: They get by on the strength of their early songs and live albums, since after 1971 they haven't put out anything really vital.  In the 60s though, they played some cool blues/pop songs and recorded some of the best live shows/albums ever.  Studio albums don't do the Who the justice that Live at Leeds does.  And really, how could I not include a band that had Keith Moon, John Entwistle, Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, who are among the best drummers, bassists, singers, and songwriters respectively.

Rolling Stones: I was hesitant to put them on the list since I don't really enjoy most of the songs they recorded after the 60s.  However, the songs they recorded in the 60s were amazing.  Sure Jagger is ugly and can't really sing, but Keith Richards wrote some awesome songs that provided the Stones with the rebellious image and sound that made them successful.  Their 60s songs were bluesy and were pretty ballsy for the time period and hold up pretty well today.  The songs hold up much better than they personally do, friggin geezers.

Elvis: How oould the King not make the list?  The man is the consummate entertainer.  Sure, he's remembered for the fat, pathetic joke he became in the 1970s, but in the 50s and 60s he was pretty freaking cool.  The 68 Comeback Special is one of the most memorable and one of my most favorite performances ever.  Say what you will about his image and legacy, but the man had some soul and he could really sing, I mean really belt out the songs.  As a performer and pure singer, Elvis stands alone.

Prince: Probably an unexpected pick, but the man is so talented that it would be a shame if I didn't include him.  On his first album, he played 27 instruments!!!  27 instruments!!!  He's an absolutely amazing guitarist and as an entertainer, very few rank with him.  Listen to the songs on Purple Rain, or even his newest album Musicology.  Prince has evolved with each album and managed to put out something compelling every time out.

Bob Dylan:  I almost forgot about Dylan until "masters of war" came up on my musicmatch playlist.  He can't sing worth shit, but he's written enough amazing songs to make the list.  His influence is far reaching, he helped set the stage for Hendrix and Tom Petty and Bruce Springsteen.  He has enough great songs to fill his own entry.  He has a way with lyrics and through them has crafted a plethora of songs that stand out today.  I would name some, but I'm pretty sure everyone can name at least one Bob Dylan song.  I feel sheepish about forgetting him since he's such a no brainer.

Black Flag:  Probably the only pick besides Prince that I feel like I should really defend.  Basically, Black Flag owned the hardcore punk scene in the early 1980s and expanded it to include heavy metal.  If one listens to the tribute album that Rollins put out a year or two ago, you can hear how much they influenced hardcore.  The heaviness and power in bands like Nirvana and Slipknot were made possible by Black Flag.  They sang of alienation and isolation and society and anger and did it better than most everyone.  On top of that, Greg Ginn was an amazing guitarist and Black Flag provided Henry Rollins his start.  Basically, Black Flag took metal and punk, combined them and created a whole new sound.

Honorable Mention:  Janis Joplin, the Misfits, Cream, Jimi Hendrix, Aerosmith

Well, that is that.  Please do not hesitate to post your top ten list, I am really eager to see what you came up with!

The 2005 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees were announced recently, with the Pretenders and U2 being the two marquee names being enshrined.  There was a band that was eligible this year but not accepted into the Hall.  A band that put out three seminal albums and created the punk genre before it existed.  That band would be the Stooges, better known now as Iggy Pop and the Stooges.  I would like to take this time to make the case for the immediate inclusion of the Stooges into the Hall and for the immediate denial of any critical acclaim for U2.

The Stooges were way ahead of their time.  Listen to their three albums recorded from 1969-1973.  They were punk before the label existed.  Big, loud, distorted riffs and alienated, brutal, and nihilistic lyrics were Stooge trademarks.  It was the end of the flower power movement and here were Iggy and the Stooges recording songs like "I Wanna be your Dog," "TV Eye," "No Fun," and "Search and Destroy."  At the time, the Stooges were hated.  The critics and record labels thought the music was stupid and abrasive.  Due to the violent nature of their songs and performances and record label opposition, the Stooges collapsed.  What arose from their demise less than a decade later was the punk movement.  They laid the groundwork for the Sex Pistols (who used to regularly cover "No Fun") and Black Flag and all the other bands that helped make punk popular.  The three Stooges albums are much more vital and interesting than anything that newer bands have put out.  Most bands weren't as daring as the Stooges, lyrically, visually and musically.  Within their sound were elements of jazz and bohemia that David Bowie would later use.  Also, the lyrics might have been viewed as stupid, but really they were just a harbinger of what was to come by the end of the 1970s.  Even if critics dislike their music and style, they should be at least recognized for their influence.  I mean, I like the Talking Heads and they were inducted a few years ago, but I tend to think that Iggy and the Stooges were a bit more influential on the history of rock music.

This brings me to a band that I believe is quite possibly the most overrated band ever, U2.  First of all, the band itself is pretty untalented, and not untalented in a cool way like the Ramones.  The Edge plays the same solo and usually the same riff in every song, the rhythm section is weak, and Bono isn't exactly a quality singer.  And I don't want to hear that "hes singing from the heart" shit.  Dude just cannot sing well.  I could go out and yell like he does and put on a falsetto and people would just call me a jackass.  I think it has to do with the fact that he's being "political," like no other band has done that before.  Well, the Clash did it a good 5 years before U2 and they did it with a lot more musical diversity than U2.  The last two U2 albums have been hailed as staggering works of genius, but they both are the same basic album.  Really, most U2 songs sound exactly alike.  You can count some tearful wailing from Bono, the one note solo from Edge, and an overall sound that the critics will hail as "brilliant" and "groundbreaking" and "a breath of fresh air."  How can every new U2 song and album be groundbreaking and fresh when the last two or three albums have all been carbon copies of each other?  Since the Joshua Tree, the only difference is that they have become easier on the ears.  They just sounded like a mess on some of the early songs.  I will grant that they are at best an average band, but they are accepted because of the fact that Bono is trying to eradicate AIDS, war, hunger, and poverty across the third world.  To which I say, Bono has a messiah complex and Joe Strummer was championing these causes way before it was hip.  Overall, I feel that U2 was a second rate Clash that has managed to stay vital through their public image.  The music wasn't new and revolutionary when they started in 1979 and it certainly isn't groundbreaking or new in 2005.  The music of U2 didn't create a new genre of rock and didn't really add anything new to the mix.

That is why I suggest that at the very least, the Stooges need to be inducted immediately.  From this day forth, U2 should no longer be referred to as the greatest rock band on the planet and the greatest thing since the Beatles.  Bono should no longer be mentioned in the same breath as Jesus and each new U2 album shouldnt be called the greatest piece of music since the last U2 album.  To beat this dead horse of an entry even more, how can the Stooges be denied but the Pretenders are accepted?  Seriously, the Pretenders make U2 look like Led Zeppelin.  The Pretenders are neither vital nor particularly influential in the overall history of rock music.  Basically, Iggy and the Stooges = awesomeness and Bono, Chrissy Hynde, and the people who select the inductees into the Hall of Fame should be clubbed like the sots they are.

I don't really have anything of any particular importance to say right now, but I feel like putting something down here to kill some time before I do some schoolwork.  So, with that being said, I made a mix today of some stuff I have been listening to and I decided that right now I am going to put down the song list and supply you, my devoted audience, with some morsels of my thoughts as to why I put them on this cd.

1) Motley Crue - Shout at the Devil:  Well, with the news last week that the Crue is back together for a reunion tour next year, I felt obligated to put them back in my playlist rotation.  This song is probably my alltime favorite Motley Crue song and is probably one of the best songs they've done (more on that when I do an artist profile on them some time in the future).  It's a great song to open the mix with since it has a lot of energy and really just rocks as much as or more than anything else that has come out in the 20 years since this song came out.

2) Brides of Destruction - Natural Born Killers:  Brides of Destruction is a "supergroup" consisting of the drummer of Adema, the guitarist of L.A. Guns, Nikki Sixx from Motley Crue, and an unknown singer.  Alright, so they might not really be a supergroup but I still think this song is cool.  It has a pretty cool riff, the singer (named London)does a decent job singing the song, some dumb lyrics, but overall its enjoyable.  London's singing is the weakest part of the song and really all their songs since he is kind of a lame version of Chris Cornell and Gary Cherone of Extreme (and it don't get much lamer than Gary Cherone folks).  Despite that, I like this song, it has a good flow to it and it's easy to sing along with.

3) Brides of Destruction - Shut the Fuck Up:  This song is one of the weaker songs on the mix.  It really only made it because the music to it is sick.  It has a heavy riff and background vocals that remind me of old school Misfits songs.  Other than that, the lyrics are easy to sing along to, but are still pretty stupid.  And London's voice is pretty annoying on it; if the Brides had a better singer and didn't put a stupid skit in front of this song, it would be a lot better.  Despite that, I'll buy pretty much anything Nikki Sixx puts out since he's cool as hell.

4) Soundgarden - Burden in my Hand: Chris Cornell is amazing.  His vocal range is ridiculous and he gets to show a lot of that on this song.  I stumbled upon this song when downloading a bunch of random Soundgarden songs and man am I glad I got this one.  Out of the first four songs on the mix, this easily has the best lyrics and vocal performance.  It's not as murky sounding as a lot of Soundgarden songs and the music to it matches up to the quality that Cornell brings to everything he does.  It's also not as long and drawn out as other Soundgarden songs, making this one pretty freaking good.

5) Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds - Stagger Lee:  This song, for lack of a better description, is fucking crazy.  This song is a cover of an old rhythm and blues standard, but Cave changed the lyrics into something completely different.  This is a song that most would find disturbing, since it contains references to drinking, murder, fellatio, homosexuality, and more murder.  Add to that the classic Nick Cave sound and you get a song that is a compelling listen, even if "normal" people should be repulsed.

6) Primus - Pork Soda:  Les Claypool has made some pretty demented music and this song is no exception.  I have no idea what the lyrics to this song are, much less what they are about, since his crazy redneck warble is pretty much incoherent on this song.  What's awesome about this song is the music to it.  Claypool is a fantastic bass player and this song shows off his talent.  The bass is heavy as hell and the drummer and guitarist do their part.  I usually listen to this song on my computer, but when placed in any stereo worth a damn, I was blown away by how heavy the rhythm is.  This isn't Primus' best or even most fun song, but it's pretty freaking good.

7) Nine Inch Nails - We're in this Together: Trent Reznor has written and recorded so many amazing songs.  His lyrics are usually depressing and/or violent and this song has some fairly bleak lyrics, the way they are sung within the music almost makes this song sound hopeful.  His vocals on the song are really compelling (I've alreayd overused that word, but it's still the best descriptor I have).  Everyone focuses on how hopeless and depressed Reznor usually is, but he has created some amazing melodies that make any whining sound enjoyable.  At the very least, one can dance to his uptempo songs.  This song has a pretty good riff to it and even though it clocks in at 7 minutes, it doesn't feel that long.  All in all, this song is a pretty fun listen for a Nine Inch Nails song, even for those who aren't really fans.

8) Pantera - Cowboys From Hell:  In honor of Dimebag Darell I had to put one Pantera song in and this one happens to be my favorite.  He played a lot of great riffs and this one is one of my favorites of any guitarist, ever.  The song isn't as hardcore as other Pantera songs, but don't hold that against it.  Besides the great riff, Phil Anselmo provides a cool vocal performance that smacks of both 80s glam and hard rock.  This song puts a smile on my face when I hear it.  Plain and simple, Cowboys from Hell is pretty kickass.

9) Anthrax and Public Enemy - Bring Tha Noise:  Public Enemy is one of the greatest rap groups ever and Anthrax is one of the best bands in the metal genre, so the combination of the two works really well.  Chuck D's imposing voice is backed up strongly by the music Anthrax provides.  This is a great song to get pumped up to and is, in my humble opinion, the best combination of rap and rock ever.  Chuck D's voice is always so commanding and the heavy sound provided by Anthrax amplifies it about a million times.

10) Green Day - Boulevard of Broken Dreams:  This is one of my favorite songs off the American Idiot album.  It is a familiar Green Day sound, but it is something different at the same time.  Within the concept of the American Idiot album the song works perfectly and it stands up well on its own as a single.  Billy Joe's voice isn't annoying on it and the music is pretty simple, but more complex than what one would expect from Green Day.

11) Nine Inch Nails - The Fragile:  Another Nine Inch Nails song that isn't as depressing or as violent as the rest of their catalog of songs.  This song is really a love song about being someone's support even when things get tough.  The gradual rise in the music and the vocals from soft and quiet to loud and heavy really works well and makes it something different from Trent Reznor, but different in a good way.

12) The Nightwatchman - Union Song:  The Nightwatchman is Tom Morello playing acoustic and singing, unaccompanied by anyone else.  His voice is far from being great, but it works as a standard folk song.  The lyrics are imbibed with the political message that Morello fans have come to expect and his style of "singing" works well with the lyrics and the simple, uptempo strumming on the guitar.  This song made it on the mix as a way to change up the pace of the mix, as well as providing a fun little break after the heavy sound of Nine Inch Nails.

13) U2 - Vertigo:  U2 is far from being one of my favorite bands, but I enjoy Vertigo greatly.  For one song, Bono wasn't whiny and self-important and the band took a break from using the same guitar and rhythm sounds that they've used for the last 25 years.  This song is a fun U2 song, something that they don't have many of. 14) The Raveonettes - That Great Love Sound:  A modern garage rock song that doesn't suck, this song reminds me of some of the pop-rock songs of the 50s and 60s.  The vocals on the song are sung jointly by a male and a female and they provide a decent harmony.  The lyrics are catchy and easy to sing with.  It doesn't have that forced sound that I think other garage bands like the Strokes or the Hives have.  It sounds natural and would have been a monstrous hit 35-40 years ago.

15) Iggy and the Stooges - Down on the Street:  The Stooges are one of the baddest and heaviest bands ever and the fact that they didn't get voted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame this year really irks me, but I digress.  Iggy is the baddest man in rock history and even now at like 60 years old could still beat the shit out of any current rock act.  Down on the Street rocks like few songs have since.  I wrote about it a few weeks ago, so I'm not going to spend much time on it, other than to say that this song and all of the Stooges albums are essentials for any fan of real punk and hard rock.  This song has brutal vocals and brutal music put to them and really, that is that.

16) The Doors - Peace Frog:  This song is probably my favorite Doors song.  I've talked about this one before too, so I'll try to keep it simple.  Krieger supplied a funky riff and Morrison brought his sweet vocals and some unique lyrics to this one.  It has an amazing groove and despite this being near the end of the Doors and of Morrison's life, he actually sounded like he wanted to sing this one.

17) Black Flag - My War:  I didn't put this on the mix for any particular reason other than the fact it is my favorite Black Flag song.  It picks up the intensity that drops in the mix between Down on the Street and Peace Frog and adds to it tenfold.  Rollins is screaming at his manic best and Greg Ginn plays loud and furiously.  I've talked about this song before, so I won't say too much more about it other than the fact that it is probably Black Flag at the peak of their career.

18) Velvet Revolver - Slither:  I hadn't heard this song or put it on any mix in a while, so I gave it the coveted closing spot.  This song really combines the best of Stone Temple Pilots with the best of Guns 'N' Roses, while at the same time standing up to the legacy both bands left.  While I don't like Velvet Revolver as much as I like the two bands their music came out of, this song is heavy and rocks like no other band in the mainstream has in a long time.  And it's nice to hear this song and know that Scott Weiland, Slash, and Duff aren't dead.

That is that.  Maybe at some point I'll update again with something of some importance, but I'm not making any promises.

Breaking from the theme of classic acts, today I am going to write about one of my alltime favorite groups, Collective Soul.  Led by frontman Ed Roland, their first album entitled Hints, Allegations and Things Left Unsaid came out in 1993.  This album sold well due to the massive success of their first single, "Shine."  It also contained a solid mix of southern rock with classic Elton John style pop.  What many people don't know about the first album is that Ed Roland wrote and recorded all the songs on the album, then formed the group after he got a record deal.  In 1995, their self-titled second album came out.  This album sold well due to the success of the singles "The World I Know," "December," "Where the River Flows," and "Gel."  In general the album fit into the popular alternative sounds of the time, but with Collective Soul's southern roots distinguishing them from the pack.  Their third album, "Disciplined Breakdown" came out about two years later and had a similar sound to their previous effort.  I don't believe that it sold well, which is a shame because great songs like "Precious Declaration," "Listen," and "Blame" were on it.  Their fourth album Dosage came out around 1999 and contained the hit single "Heavy."  The album was a departure from their previous albums.  A more electronic sound exists throughout the album, making it more of a heavy pop album instead of their southern alt-pop sound.  This sound evolved more in their fifth album, Blender.  "Why Pt. 2" was a fairly popular radio song, but the album didn't sell all that well.  Blender took that electronic sound from Dosage and went further with it, and the album is basically a pop album in the vein of Elton John and John Lennon.  Collective Soul then took a long break, featuring a greatest hits compilation, and have just recently put out their newest album yet entitled Youth.  This album continues on the path of Blender, but adds in a pinch of classic 70s glam into their pop sounds.

Well, as I said above, Collective Soul is one of my favorite bands ever.  I became a fan of theirs back when "December" came out and I have stuck with them since.  I enjoy their new albums, but its weird because their distinguishing qualities they used to get noticed are a lot different now.  It seems like Ed Roland traded in his southern man vocals for sleeker, pop styling.  It sounds great but I wouldn't mind hearing him go back to it once in a while.  I saw them live a few years back and they sounded just as they do on their albums, which is a good thing.  It was a good thing because there was no drop off in quality and ability.  At the very least, every Collective Soul album has been at the very least listenable and at the very most, a lot of fun.

Songs to Hear: December, Simple, Goodnight Good Guy, Needs, Energy, Where the River Flows, Gel, Love Lifted Me, Perfect Day (featuring Elton John), Listen

Albums to Hear: Self-titled, Disciplined Breakdown, Blender

Everyone knows the story of the Beatles and there is so much to tell about it, so I'll keep it simple.  The Beatles consisted of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, and Ringo Starr.  They honed their craft in Germany through the late fifties and the beginning of the sixties.  The Beatles came to America in 1964, they were the escape America sought in the aftermath of the Kennedy assassination.  Their infectious pop tunes took the nation by storm and the Beatles overtook Elvis as the top act in America.  Record after record, the Beatles music and Beatlemania took the world by storm.  Their popularity vastly exceeded that of any band prior and has only come close to being replicated by the aura Michael Jackson used to have before he went off the deep end.  In 1966, the Beatles revolutionized what an album could be with Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.  They were the first band to take in Indian influences, Bob Dylan stylings, and combine it with their own sensibilities.  They also changed what a band could do with their movies A Hard Day's Night, Help, Magical Mystery Tour, and Let It Be.  In the late 1960s, Lennon and McCartney had a battle of egos and George Harrison began to develop as a songwriter.  This led to the amazing White Album, Abbey Road, and Let it Be.  Lennon was highly experimental, Harrison was developing his own style, McCartney kept on plugging along with the sound that he still has today, and Ringo was Ringo.  Eventually, the egos and the changes in their lifestyles caused the Beatles to split up officially in 1970.  Lennon went on to put out songs that were either amazing or shit, before being killed in 1980.  Harrison had a few successful solo albums and really spent a lot of time out of the mainstream until dying in 2001.  McCartney has a very successful solo career and still sells out massive venues worldwide.  Ringo played Mr. Conductor on Shining Time Station and had a few hit singles that were penned by Harrison.

Some claim that the Beatles are overrated, others rank them with Jesus.  Really, the best band ever is subjective.  However, that being said, I would say that the Beatles are the most important band of all time.  No band before had ever went through the sheer craziness of what they endured.  No band prior and since have been such a cultural phenomenon.  Their music still is madly popular, as evidenced by the hits compilation "1" being the top selling album worldwide of 2001.  The Beatles basically created the pop genre and the whole concept of pop stars.  The early years get all the acclaim, but I personally prefer their work from Sgt. Pepper through Let It Be.  It was so experimental but so good, much better in my opinion than the naive pop of the early years.  This leads to the next part, my favorite Beatle.  My favorite is John Lennon, but George Harrison is close behind.  Lennon wrote and sang songs like "Revolution" and so many other anthems that live on today.  Harrison was vastly underrated as a songwriter and guitarist, his slide guitar work and his soft vocal style are a really nice change of things.  McCartney is an amazing bassist and he wrote many great songs, but he has spent a lot of time over the years trying to become known as the creative influence behind the band.  Also, they were the ones responsible for the British invasion that brought along the Rolling Stones, the Kinks, Dave Clark Five, and the Who.  Luckily there has never been any attempt to reform or create the Beatles by the band members, so their body of work and legacy remains largely intact.

Unfortunately, drugs and alcohol tore the band apart in the late 1970s.  Perry and Whitford were replaced by the vastly inferior Jimmy Crespo and Rick Dufay, and Steven Tyler was smacked out of his mind and was near death.  In the early 80s, Aerosmith cleaned up and reunited for the album Done With Mirrors, a commercial flop and a huge step down from the raunchy blues crunch of their early albums. Aerosmith got a shot in the arm commercially when Run DMC redid "Walk This Way," giving Aerosmith a whole new fanbase and a new chance to succeed.  They did so with the albums Permanent Vacation and PUMP, which were huge commercial successes and host to several top ten singles. By 1992 and the release of Get a Grip, the creative team of Perry and Tyler were writing songs with the top pop songwriters in order to record pop rock hits.  This bore songs like "Crazy," "Cryin'" and the only Aerosmith song to go to number 1, "I Don't Wanna Miss a Thing."  By the release of Just Push Play, pretty much all Aerosmith songs were being written by people other than the band and Aerosmith went from being one of the alltime greatest hard rock/blues based bands to a successful pop act.  2003 saw Aerosmith return to their blues roots with the cover album Honkin' on Bobo, an album which some lauded as Aerosmith's successful return to their blues roots and criticized by others as too little too late in Aerosmith's hopes of regaining some of their blues credibility.

My own opinion is that Aerosmith should not record any more new albums.  Nothing that they have put out in the last 18 years matches up to their first four albums in terms of quality.  Aerosmith has traded in their reputation as one of the best bands of the 70s and of all time in order to become commercially viable and sell records.  They could have been like the Rolling Stones and put out their own albums just to put out their own music, regardless of success and toured on their reputation.  Despite the fact that I think they sold out their rock roots, they are a very good pop rock band even if Steven Tyler's voice is on the verge of dying.  Their old songs were fresh and had funky grooves for a group of white boys from Boston.  Joe Perry is one of my favorite guitarists and his style is distinct and raunchy and fun to hear.  Whitford and Hamilton are extremely underrated and Joey Kramer can hold his own.  I saw them live last year when they toured with KISS and they were surprisingly subpar and heavily favored the newer pop songs over their classic material.  "Jaded" will never make me get pumped like "Back in the Saddle" and "I Don't Wanna Miss A Thing" will never be as powerful a song as "Dream On."  If only Aerosmith was more concerned with being who they always were instead of playing just to be popular.

Ten Songs to Hear:  Seasons of Wither, Walk This Way, Back in the Saddle, Mama Kin, Walkin' The Dog, Same Old Song and Dance, Walk on Water, Train Kept A Rollin', Lord of the Thighs, Sweet Emotion
Albums to Hear: Self Titled Debut, Get Your Wings, Rocks

I was sitting around here and felt obligated to write something, but not anything of real weight.  As much as I enjoy being the rain on everyone's parade, I just don't really have anything to rail and wax poetic about. Instead, I am just going to put a list of songs that I enjoy and some reasons why I think everyone should know them.  This is a warm up run for my new concept in December.  Starting December 1, I am going to devote one entry a day to a musical artist who I think warrants my special attention.  This will include a brief overview of band members, band history, favorite songs, and reasons for liking or disliking said artist.  But in the meantime, this list of songs should satiate the the thirst for my thoughts.  I'm going to try to keep this list down to one song per artist and if there is an artist who I like several songs by, odds are that they will be included in the December experiment.

Peace Frog by the Doors - There are a ton of songs by the Doors that I really enjoy, like When the Music's Over or Soul Kitchen, or countless others.  This one however has all anyone needs in a song from crazy lyrics about blood and dead Indians and LA and summer, to Morrison's solid vocal work, to the groove oriented riff.  Kind of weak as far as the full awesomeness of the Doors goes, but its a really fun song to listen to.

I Wanna Be Your Dog by Iggy and the Stooges - The definitive Stooges song, even though Down on the Street is a very very close second.  The Stooges were punk before punk even existed and this song shows it.  Everything in it, from the feedback, to the primal urgency of the guitar and bass lines, to the fucked up lyrics that only Iggy Pop can sing.  Seriously, who else can sing about wanting someone so desperately that they want to be their dog?  NO ONE!!

Hybrid Moments by the Misfits - This song almost sounds romantic, until you realize that Danzig is singing about the look on a woman's face before he kills her.  Despite that, it sounds like a 50s romantic song being played by a band on speed.  Everyone who claims to be punk should have the Misfits on their playlists, they just don't make music like it anymore.

My War by Black Flag - Speaking of punk, Black Flag is the real deal.  My War is a classic punk tale of alienation and anger and loneliness as only Henry Rollins can scream.  This song, album, and band were lightyears ahead of other punk bands and this song more than adequately sums up for me the way I feel about the world sometimes in a way I can't express.

Black Betty by Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds - It's really hard to pick just one Nick Cave song to talk about, but I have to go with this one.  It is, plain and simple, fucking crazy.  Even without talking about murder, Satan, drugs, and all the other oddball topics of his normals songs, Black Betty is still amazing.  It has simplistic and almost tribal music, crazy lyrics about a lamb, and wild vocals that sound like they come from slave songs, folk songs, and tribal chants.  I know it doesn't sound impressive, but it is really like nothing I have ever heard before from Nick Cave or from anyone else for that matter.  Most normal, well adjusted people probably wouldn't give this song the time of day, but this one gets played and played often in my room.

Working Class Hero by John Lennon - While Imagine gets most, if not all, the glory, Working Class Hero is an equally amazing song.  This song just hooks a listener with its simple acoustic backing and Lennon's passionate and angered opinion of the treatment of the lower classes by the rich.  This song stands the test of time even now, as the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.  A more biting social commentary is hard to be found than the one in this song.

Welcome to the Terrordome by Public Enemy - I love Public Enemy.  Chuck D is probably my all-time favorite MC.  Public Enemy songs always bring social commentary and a feeling of empowerment to make changes in the world.  Welcome to the Terrordome has amazing beats and samples and Chuck D's rapping COMMANDS your attention and honestly, I love the phrase "Welcome to the Terrordome."

Thunderkiss '65 by White Zombie - Just an all around cool song.  I can't dance, but if I could, this song would make me do it.  The riff to this song has been burned into my memory and every time I hear it, I start to bob my head to it.  Damned if I know what the lyrics mean or what the hell Rob Zombie is saying in it, but despite that his "singing" on the track kicks major ass.

My Way by Butch Walker - This is the song that introduced me to Butch Walker.  It has that big rock sound from the 80s with just a smidge of the old school punk "fuck you" mentality and just a dash of power pop.  I love songs that are about being yourself and not conforming to what everyone else wants and this song is the best modern version of that style.  I dare you to listen to this song and not sing along.

Hurt by Johnny Cash - The greatest cover song of alltime, bar none.  There's really not much I can say about this song that hasn't been said by everyone else.  That doesn't mean I won't try though.  This song is so haunting, yet moving at the same time.  Johnny Cash took a Nine Inch Nails song about heroin addiction and turned it into his swan song, a sadly prophetic piece about nearing the end of his life.  Cash took a fairly current, Grammy winning song and made it into his own.  So good that no one can really ever cover it again and bring the same emotion to it.
